newsitem.title: USA: US blue chips end higher, boosted by bond rally.
newsitem.headline: US blue chips end higher, boosted by bond rally.

text.p: The Dow industrials finished higher on Tuesday, powered by a strong performance in the bond market after fresh evidence the U.S. economy continues to grow at a moderate pace.
The Dow rose 50 points to close unofficially at 7722, paced by financial stocks J.P. Morgan & Co Inc, which rose 3-1/8 to 107-1/2, and Travelers Group Inc, which gained 1-5/8 to 64-11/16.
Early in the session, stocks and bonds got a boost from a key monthly report on U.S. manufacturing activity.

The new information came from the National Association of Purchasing Management's (NAPM) monthly survey, which showed an increase in U.S. manufacturing activity in June, though at a slower pace than economists had expected.

The report was soothing after Monday's stronger- than-expected regional manufacturing surveys, which prompted last-minute jitters over the Federal Reserve's interest rate policy meeting, which began Tuesday and ends on Wednesday.
"I don't think anybody's scared at this point," said Arnie Owen, managing director of capital markets at Cruttenden Roth. "I certainly don't think anyone sees any inflation out there."

Bonds shot higher after the report, sending the yield on the benchmark 30-year U.S. Treasury down five basis points to 6.74 percent, and stocks quickly followed, led by interest rate-sensitive sectors such as finance and transportation.
Airlines were among the strongest performers, with Delta Air Lines Inc rising 1-13/16 to 84-7/16 and Southwest Airlines Co leaping 1-5/8 to 27-1/2.

Early in the day, Southwest was cited on Lehman Brothers' annual list of 10 "uncommon values," a portfolio of stocks the firm believes will outperform the Standard & Poor's 500 index over the next 12 months.

While Wall Street is nearly unanimous in expecting the Fed will leave interest rates steady, it still faces a critical test in the monthly data on U.S. payrolls and wages. The report is due out Thursday, instead of its traditional Friday release, because of the Independence Day-shortened work week.
Between the employment figures and the Fed meeting, analysts said market action could be quite contained over the next session.
"In the past we've hesitated before employment reports and before Fed meetings and this week we have both," said Gregory Nie, technical analyst at EVEREN Securities.
Among individual issues, Office Depot Inc tumbled 3-13/16 to 15-5/8 in the first trading since Monday's court ruling blocking the company's planned merger with Staples Inc.
Shares in Staples, generally considered to be the stronger of the two office-supply retailers by analysts, rose 1-1/16 to 24-5/16.
Boeing Co gained one point to 54-1/16 after the company won unconditional approval from U.S. regulators for its merger with McDonnell Douglas Corp. McDonnell Douglas rose 1-3/16 to 69-11/16.

Pierce Leahy Corp jumped 5-9/16 to 23-9/16 in its New York Stock Exchange debut. Pierce Leahy, based in King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, manages archived records including paper records, microfilm and video tapes.
The Nasdaq Composite fell 3.82 points to 1438.25.
